snippet.title: Should The State Intervene In Religious Practices?
snippet.description:
Fasting has been an integral part of organized religion in India. Sometimes fasting is undertaken for the betterment of worldly life and at times for renunciation of material comfort. But the 'Lakshman Rekha' was breached when Aradhana Samdhariya - a 13-year-old girl - suffered a fatal heart attack after completing a fast that lasted 68 days. Her death shocked the country, as her funeral procession was turned into a 'shobha yatra' in an attempt by her community to extol her virtues. It was only after the Child Rights Organizations filed a complaint that a case of culpable homicide not amounting to murder was registered against the Jain teen's parents.

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/should-the-state-intervene-in-religious-practices-435143?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is Aam Aadmi Party imploding?
snippet.description:
First came the purge of founder members of AAP from the party, then a series of arrests of AAP MLAs followed by CDs indicting AAP leaders of corruption, sex scandals. The party, which has always prided itself for being different - offering a transparent governance based on principles of non-corruption, high moral and ethical values - suddenly seemed like any other political party. However, the real sting in the criticism has come from none other than the anti-corruption crusader Anna Hazare who had 'high hopes' from Arvind Kejriwal. The veteran has questioned  AAP chief's style of functioning and criticised him on not paying due diligence while appointing members and ministers. In its defence. the AAP has cited a number of cases where courts have questioned the motive of Delhi police and the vindictive nature of the Modi government? The question everyone is asking is - what has happened to AAP - is it imploding?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-is-aam-aadmi-party-imploding-430805?yt

snippet.title: The future is in your mobile
snippet.description:

snippet.title: The Big Fight | PM's Presidential Pitch: Is It Advantage Modi?
snippet.description:
On The Big Fight, we discuss with more than half the Parliament seats having voted now, and with  four phases left, who has the edge in this campaign? Has this election now become almost completely about Narendra Modi rather than a seat-by-seat fight? And does that give Mr Modi the advantage? Joining us on the show, Congress communication in charge Randeep Surjewala says that PM has nothing to show for his five years of work, while actor Richa Chadha says the PM should hold a press conference and take questions on jobs and agrarian crisis. BJP's Vivek Reddy responds by saying that when the opposition only talks about PM Modi he responds accordingly. This and much more on The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Should reservation be determined by caste or religion?
snippet.description:
Just as we saw the demand for publication of caste-based data subside, a 22-year-old youth belonging to the Patel community in Gujarat burst into the scene demanding that Patels be included in the OBC (Other Backward Classes) list. Hardik Patel created a stir by gathering lakhs of Patels for the cause and by issuing a firm warning to the government of a continuous agitation if demands were not met. Vice President Hamid Ansari, highlighting the plight of Muslims also demanded affirmative action for the community but stopped short of demanding any reservation. Is reservation the only tool for the marginalised, backward communities for empowerment? Is it more of a political path of expressing the plight and might of your community to be recognised as a homogenous votebank? What about doing away with reservations at the IITs and IIMs? Finally, should reservation be determined by caste or religion? Should social and economic empowerment be the only criteria?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/should-reservation-be-determined-by-caste-or-religion/381716

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Serving 'Thalinomics': Can India Regain Its Economic Appetite?
snippet.description:
On the eve of the budget, the government presented its Economic Survey, pegging GDP growth at 5% for this fiscal - a sharp decline of the 7% it had predicted last year but the CEA says growth will pick up next year in the financial year going up to around 6-6.5%. On The Big Fight, we ask, can India regain its economic appetite?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are we becoming an intolerant nation?
snippet.description:
The gruesome murder of Mohammad Akhlaq in Dadri, Uttar Pradesh over rumours of storing beef has brought the question of growing intolerance in today's India to the fore. It took more than a week for the Prime Minister to speak out against the growing intolerance that afflicts us. All of this begs the question, is there an attempt to make India a singular, culturally monotheistic country? Should PM Modi have spoken sooner to send a strong message to the mischief makers? Is social media contributing to chaos? Did the luminaries of India's freedom movement ever envisage that our country will be at a crossroad where the whole idea of a pluralistic India would be under threat? We debate on The Big Fight.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-are-we-becoming-an-intolerant-nation/386389?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Government Tackling Fake News Or Muzzling The Press?
snippet.description:
It has been a busy week for journalists around the country as the government came out with a controversial order stating that journalists stand a chance to lose accreditation if they create or circulate 'fake news'. The order led to enormous backlash by the journalistic community that saw the move as a way to muzzle the press. The Modi government was quick to react, as the circular was revoked on the orders of the Prime Minister. However later in the week, there was another controversial announcement over the formation of a committee to regulate online news, with not a single member from the platform to represent them. Could this be seen as an attempt by the government to keep a tab on online content? Is it better for the media to be its own watchdog? For all this and more watch this week's episode of The Big Fight and write in to us at bigfight@ndtv.com with your comments and suggestions

snippet.title: Pathankot terror attack: Litmus test for PM Modi's Pakistan policy?
snippet.description:
It is a trying time for Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his foreign policy vis-a-vis Pakistan. The warmth shared between the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan saw rough weather as Pakistan-based terrorists infiltrated India's airbase in Pathankot. In a detailed operation that spread across a couple of days, Indian forces having suffered casualties themselves managed to eliminate the air base and secure it. However, this put a big question mark over the future of Indo-Pak talks as India has demanded prompt action by the government in Pakistan. What does this mean for Indo-Pak relations? Should talks continue despite terror attacks? Does this undermine the Prime Minister's efforts at peace with Pakistan?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/pathankot-terror-attack-litmus-test-for-pm-modi-s-pakistan-policy/398193?yt

snippet.title: 'Tough Decision' on J&K: Change In Nuclear No-First Use Doctrine Next?
snippet.description:
Union Defence Minister Rajnath Singh today underscored that India reserves the right to change its policy of 'No First Use', which has been the cornerstone of India's nuclear weapons policy for decades. The government firmly stands by its 'No First Use' policy but "what happens in future will depend on the circumstances," the minister said at Pokhran in Rajasthan. The statement comes a day after the PM announced the creation of the post of Chief of Defence Staff. On The Big Fight, we discuss the consequences of making such statements in the current environment.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Growth Forecast Down: Is Economy In Free Fall?
snippet.description:
Is India's economy in free fall? Growth numbers are down, industrial production is down, auto sales are also down, while new data shows poverty may have actually gone up. This week, India's largest public sector bank State Bank of India said Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth will slow down further to 4.2 per cent in the second quarter of this year, after it hit a six-year low of 5 per cent in the first quarter. SBI has also rolled back its forecasts for India's GDP growth for the current fiscal from 6.1 per cent earlier to just 5 per cent now. The telecom sector is facing a huge crisis, but there is some hope for them after indications that the government could step in to bail them out. A report in Business Standard newspaper showed that consumer spending has fallen in 2017-18 for the first time in more than four decades, primarily driven by slackening rural demand, which experts say points to a rise in poverty, according to data complied by the National Statistical Office (NSO).

snippet.title: The Big Fight: The Aadhaar Verdict - Who Won?
snippet.description:
On this episode of The Big Fight we discuss the recent judgement on Aadhaar. This verdict has bearings not just for the unique identity project itself, it has broader implications for privacy, technology and the role it should play in our lives. Are we going to go digital? We are going to try and take a look at some of the broader implications of this.

snippet.title: Is PM Modi soft on Kashmir, tough on Pakistan?
snippet.description:
The Prime Minister's Independence Day speech from the ramparts of the Red Fort was remarkable for one reason - the gratitude he extended towards the people of Balochistan, Gilgit & PoK. Was it simply an off-the-cuff remark or was it a cool calculative step that India had been planning quietly for sometime as a bait against Pakistan's huffing and puffing over Kashmir on international forums? The other sore point that got mentioned in the Prime Minister's speech was the centre's placatory gesture towards Jammu and Kashmir and the subsequent efforts by both state and central government to stop the violence in the valley. So is this PM Modi's new game-plan of being tough on Pakistan and soft on Kashmir? Will a new set of interlocutors be able to provide the much needed 'healing touch' or will it remain only a cosmetic procedure?

snippet.title: Courts: Judicial Overreach vs Activism?
snippet.description:
The Supreme Court's latest ruling barring liquor shops, pubs, bars within 500 meters of National Highways has brought to the fore the question of whether the Judiciary is overreaching its ambit. In March this year the Court had refused to intervene in the Ayodhya dispute case suggesting amicable solution between the two warring factions. While there are a considerable number of cases where the Judiciary's intervention has been sought and lauded there are some cases where its intervention has been questioned - most notably the day-to-day running of BCCI. Critics argue that when the Courts are clogged with thousands of cases it is a futile exercise on the part of the Judiciary to spent time administering the functions of our apex cricket body. However, activists are in favour of the Court's intervention vis-a-vis subversion of fundamental rights - like access to food, healthcare, issues farm distress. Therefore we ask are the Judicial interventions due to under reach & failure on the part of the executive? Are we seeing a more pro-active role on the part of the Judiciary?

snippet.title: Religious radicalisation: A clear and present danger?
snippet.description:
It has been one of the bloodiest Ramzan in the history of Islam. Nothing and no one was spared, from Medina to Dhaka, infact it was Muslims who were killed in large numbers. The perpetrators, who owned up to the attacks, justified the killings in the name of religion. We ask: has terror got anything to do with religion? Or are fringe elements misinterpreting religious ideals for their own narrow gain? Closer to home, India has been able to ward off the surge in radicalisation yet there are concerns since one of the gunmen in  Dhaka attack proclaimed that we was influenced by an Indian preacher Dr Zakir Naik. Previously there have been sporadic reports of Indians joining ISIS. Can religious leaders in India do more to protect Indians from such radicalisation?

snippet.title: '1,000 Shades Of Grey': A Tale Of 'Capital' Pollution
snippet.description:
Like Diwali, air pollution has also become a part of north India's ritual, one that no one looks forward to but is a byproduct of everything that is wrong with urban India - mis-governance, political apathy, lack of concern for the environment, poor implementation of green laws, improper planning etc. Policymakers were well aware of the impending crisis of air pollution, but little or nothing was done to prevent it. Small yet meaningful measures such as vacuuming of roads, sprinkling of water was not done. The situation worsened further by smoke rising from crop burning in neighbouring states such as Punjab and Haryana, and cracker bursting during the festival of Diwali. Now, most of northern India sits with a cloud of deadly smog hovering over it, the air quality index hit 'severe' for several cities in the region. Experts on the show, Chandra Bhushan from Centre for Science and Environment and Dr. Guleria, a renowned Pulmonologist claimed that this air pollution could lead to thousands of deaths as the air puts at risk children as well as adults. If this is not a wake up call then what is?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/1000-shades-of-grey-a-tale-of-capital-pollution-437592?yt

snippet.title: India At 70: The Highs And Lows
snippet.description:
We are about to complete 70 years of our independence. From being the poster boy of poverty and branded as a land of snake-charmers, India has come a long way. Cynics had doubted whether India would even survive even for a few years with its experiment of being a democratic country amidst a wide range of diversity - religious, linguistic, racial to name a few. Though India has pulled out millions of people from the scourge of poverty, yet several millions still go to bed hungry. The last few decades have seen religious fault lines increasing with fundamentalism rearing its ugly head. While India is now recognised as a soft power, employment generation remains a major headache. Where do we go from here? Will India be able to reclaim its glorious past?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: The bane of triple talaq
snippet.description:
More than three decades have passed since the Supreme Court asked the government to frame a Uniform Civil Code so that helpless women suffering from the scourge of divorce could recourse to law. But with successive governments lacking political will, women are still at the receiving end. Such is the case of Shayara Banu, a 35-year-old mother of two whose husband sent the 'talaq-nama' via post. She has approached the Supreme Court which has accepted the petition. So has the time come to do away with personal laws? Should India debate and agree upon a Common Civil Code? What about the lack of political will?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Millennials And Math: New Threats To The Indian Economy?
snippet.description:
It is no secret now that India's economy is in deep trouble. The GDP is at 5 per cent, the lowest in over six years; auto sales are their lowest in over 20 years; rural wage growth has collapsed to 1 per cent in 2018-19 compared to 15 per cent in 2013-14; while unemployment is at a 45-year-high. But over the last week, much of the news has focused on the dreaded two Ms - Math and Millennials. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said the fact that millennials are using car apps like OLA and Uber is the reason car sales are down. She's got a lot of flak for it, simply because the data doesn't match her claims, and then why are truck sales also down? Then Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal said on Thursday how numbers don't matter, "after all Math didn't help Einstein discover gravity", but it did make Mr Goyal trend on Twitter all day. But that's not the point. People make mistakes. Yes, Issac Newton discovered gravity, not Albert Einstein. But the bigger point is: Is the government taking the economic slowdown as seriously as it should be? Is it time to put partisan politics aside, sit down with someone like Dr Manmohan Singh and try and find solutions?

snippet.title: Aarushi Talwar murder case: Has justice been served?
snippet.description:
It has been almost two years since the curtain came down on the Aarushi Talwar murder case when the lower court convicted her parents - Dr Rajesh and Nupur Talwar - guilty of murdering the 14-year-old. But has justice been served? Is there enough evidence to establish the guilt of the parents beyond any reasonable doubt? Or are the real culprits still at large? What was the role of the media in this highly publicised trial? Did the media end up affecting not just public opinion but also the judiciary? For all this and more join us on this week's episode of The Big Fight.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/aarushi-talwar-murder-case-has-justice-been-served/383585?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Janata Curfew: Trial For Future?
snippet.description:
Some health experts have said that the actual number of cases in India could be many times more than what is now being reported. The central focus is this - as India gets set for the first day of what some say is a trial lockdown on Sunday, can the country truly delay the spread of this infection to a larger community? This will be the difference in potentially saving thousands of lives. If the coronavirus becomes a community wide transmission, people may never be able to locate and isolate the source of the infection.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: A summer of polls in India
snippet.description:
As India braces for a hot summer ahead, Pondicherry, Assam, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu and Kerala are up for assembly elections. On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we take you through the election agendas in each of these states. We go live to Kolkata to find out what's mixing up in Bengal's politics. Will Chief Minister Mamata Bannerjee win a second term or will the BJP be able to make a mark in the state? In Assam, where illegal immigration is a major issue, we ask if that will play a major role in determining which party comes to power? Moving south to Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry, we see a five cornered contest as old foes, AIADMK'S Amma (mother) and DMK'S Anna (big brother) lock horns in a fight for supremacy. And as Kerala races into polls with a possible three way fight between the UDF, the LDF and the BJP?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/news/the-big-fight-a-summer-of-polls-in-india/412186?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is The Army Getting Politicised?
snippet.description:
In the run up to the Uttar Pradesh assembly elections, posters depicting the success of India's surgical strike against Pakistan along with grabs of senior BJP leaders were used in rallies. Last year the Congress publicly questioned the basis for elevating General Bipin Rawat as the Chief of Army Staff superseding other seniors. And now, after the Army awarded Major Leetul Gogoi who used a man named Farooq Dar as a human shield, there has been a barrage of criticism from human rights group, a section of the media.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-is-the-army-getting-politicised-458386?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Uttar Pradesh - The Return Of Identity Politics?
snippet.description:
Change, development, jobs, efficiency, and an end to corruption, discrimination - it was these top promises as demonstrated by his popular slogan Sabka Saath Sabka Vikas, that swayed the elections in favour of Prime Minister Narendra Modi in 2014. But two-and-half-years later, a different discourse is being heard in the Hindi heartland of Uttar Pradesh - instead of jobs, Make in India, Beti Padhao, the high-decibel campaign is now focussing on competitive communalism - allocation of money for "kabarastan and shamshan" (crematoria and burial grounds), from netas insinuating that laptops have been distributed on the basis of religion to parties boasting of fielding a sizeable number of Muslim candidates. Where does it lead us? An unending vortex of caste and identity politics from which India has been unable to pull itself out? A gargantuan obstacle that puts a leash on the immense talent and energy that the youth wants to use to build a new India - where equality is the bedrock and Vikaas (development) is the only political buzzword? A roadblock that stifles nation building from taking a sublime form and attaining the glorious height that is only bestowed to a religious ceremony?

Watch full show : http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-uttar-pradesh-the-return-of-identity-politics-450373?yt

snippet.title: Republic At 70: Is India's Democracy In Danger? | The Big Fight
snippet.description:
Over the last few months, beginning with the government's actions in Kashmir to the CAA, now India's democratic credentials are being questioned. This week, India slipped 10 places on a key world democracy index and The Economist has a cover story on India 'intolerant', while billionaire George Soros has made scathing comments on what he says is India becoming a Hindu nationalist state. The BJP may say it doesn't care what foreign publications write but they go out of their way to highlight positive coverage and the Prime Minister himself has written editorial pieces for the New York times which has been extremely critical of his government recently. On The Big Fight, we ask: Is India's democracy really in danger?

snippet.title: No country for women and children?
snippet.description:
India has been in the news the world over as a country that has no place for women, Delhi has been tagged as the rape capital of the country. In the last thirty days Indians were shocked to hear the horrific incidents of rape of a toddler, a four-year-old child and a five-year-old child in Delhi. The shock factor comes from the fact that even after a nationwide uproar vis-a-vis the Nirbhaya rape case nothing has changed on the ground. Is it a problem of policing? Will the situation change unless and until there is a change of mindset? Does the real danger emanate from kith & kin? How can we make our cities safer for our children?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/no-country-for-women-and-children/388160?yt

snippet.title: Is There A Systematic Effort To Undermine India's State Institutions?
snippet.description:
A very serious accusation was made during the course of the Gujarat elections that there was a systematic effort being made to undermine institutions. That is by itself not necessarily entirely new - you've heard about CBI being a 'caged parrot' for decades. More recently, the same charge is being made about the Enforcement Directorate, about the Income Tax Department, about other enforcement wings of the government, that they are all acting at the behest of the government to target political rivals. What is unusual is that the Election Commission was brought into it and a specific allegation was made by the Congress party saying that the Election Commission has played a biased role in the Gujarat elections and that a serious charge. Is any of this true or fair? We debate that on this week's episode of The Big Fight.

Watch full video: https://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/is-there-a-systematic-effort-to-undermine-india-s-state-institutions-474664?yt

snippet.title: Arunachal Pradesh: Stuck between Congress and BJP?
snippet.description:
The simmering political tension that was brewing in Arunachal Pradesh for the last few months reached an ugly denouement with the President dismissing the Nabam Tuki-led Congress government based on Governor Rajkhowa's report. We debate the intricacies of the Arunachal crisis, its causes and implications as the matter now rests with the Supreme Court of India. Is the Arunachal crisis really unnecessary? A peaceful state that shares a precarious border with China, Arunachal Pradesh has been claimed by China, from time to time. In this context Arunachal is crucial as it gives subversive elements a traction in a faction-ridden political environment where all stakeholders are looking to form the Government. Has the government mishandled the situation? Should the government have resisted invoking Article 356? Is centre-state relations always fraught with difficulties, if yes then who bears the brunt of such an engagement?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/arunachal-pradesh-stuck-between-congress-and-bjp/401468?yt

http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/arunachal-pradesh-stuck-between-congress-and-bjp/401468

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Are Students The New Opposition?
snippet.description:
India is witnessing student protests across campuses for weeks now - from Jamia to JNU, from AMU to DU, from Madras University to Jadavpur in Bengal - India's students are standing up and speaking out and saying they have the right to express themselves in a democracy and they won't back down. But instead of reaching out to the students, what we have seen is the might of the Indian state coming down on them in full force - whether it was the police high handedness in Jamia to the attack by masked goons in JNU a few days ago. This violence has in fact lead to further protests, the protests which started as demonstrations against the CAA seem to have morphed into something else. Actor Deepika Padukone made a huge statement this week driving up to JNU and standing in solidarity with the students. Today union minister Smriti Irani attacked Deepika Padukone, saying she stood by the people who celebrate every time a CRPF jawan is killed. Today, the Delhi police who haven't arrested a single person for the JNU violence named some suspects. The violence in JNU came in two waves. The first - a group of students, some of them masked, entered JNU's Periyar Hostel around 3:45 pm on January 5. Seen in it, JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh. The second wave came later that night when a masked mob armed with weapons attacked Sabarmati Hostel, seemingly in retaliation to the first attack. The injures suffered in this second attack were serious: Aishe herself had head injuries, so did a Professor. Witnesses say the attack was led by the ABVP. But when the police today for the first time took names of the alleged JNU attackers, the tilt was against the Left. Of the nine people they named, seven are from the Left. One of them, Aishe Ghosh. Only two of nine named today are from the ABVP.

snippet.title: Are India's GDP Growth Numbers A Myth?
snippet.description:
One of the biggest headlines in the last few days has been about whether India genuinely has the GDP growth rate that the government says we do. Arvind Subramanian, the former Chief Economic Advisor to the government, has, in article, said that India wasn't growing at 7 per cent. It was growing at about 4.5 per cent. Mr Subramanian says no political motives can be ascribed to his study which he has down at Harvard in the US. Now, the government has responded - they've said India follows meticulous standards in coming out with data. But let's look all around us - the job numbers indicate a slowdown. The auto sector, a huge contributor to GDP is in deep trouble and more than 100 experts have said that there is something wrong with the data that India is generating.

snippet.title: The political fight: Where is the conciliatory tone?
snippet.description:
The biggest news for the Modi government this year has been the passage of the GST Bill. It wouldn't have been possible had the Congress and other opposition parties refrained from supporting the government. To be fair to the BJP, the ruling party also reached out to the opposition and accepted their amendments on the bill. The question the nation is asking is why can't the government and the opposition come together and rise above partisan politics for the benefit of the nation? Why has a horrific gang-rape in Bulandshahr, Uttar Pradesh been questioned as a political conspiracy? What does the common man think when Delhi's Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal alleges that the Prime Minister is 'frustrated' and wants to 'kill him'? What happens to civility, decorum when BJP counters AAP by saying Kejriwal is 'delusional' and 'pathologically obsessive'? How degrading can our political discourse get? Can Indian politics rise above petty bickering and be truly constructional?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are we seeing a return of 'pro-poor' discourse?
snippet.description:
Indira Gandhi had won an overwhelming majority just by raising the slogan of 'Garibi Hathao'. Before her, India's second Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri had raised the slogan of 'Jai Jawan, Jai Kisan'. With a majority of Indians still struggling to find ways to enter the middle-class segment are 'pro-poor' slogans politically beneficial? If that's the reason then why is the Left - which claims to be the flag bearer of the poor, marginalised segment of India - is in a state of a terminal decline? Is the message lost somewhere in between or did the Left parties indulge in the same bourgeoisie tactics that they despise at least ideologically? Will Kanhaiya's speech show the veteran comrades of the Left a new 'way' of communication? Even if the Left parties fail to turn the tide is the discourse in the run up to 2019 general elections be predominantly Left?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-are-we-seeing-a-return-of-pro-poor-discourse/406635?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: No Country For Seniors?
snippet.description:
We all have been hearing about the demographic dividend that India has. But what rarely comes out is that the population of senior citizens is also growing at a brisk pace - more than 36 per cent according to census data between 2001 and 2011. The ageing population tragically is being accompanied with its unfortunate elements of loneliness, abuse, neglect and a rise in number of cases of geriatrics. But this was not the case. The rise of nuclear families has cut the support system which used to sustain and form a support group for the elderly is slowly being eroded and the rising cost of healthcare and frailties are forcing them to take succor at old-age homes. Less than 30 per cent of senior citizens have a pension cover and the increase lifespan is making it even more difficult for them to be financially independent. Is going back to the ways of joint families the way out? Or should  the government ensure a slew of social security measures for seniors?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-no-country-for-seniors-461110?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Vikas Dubey: The Truth About Politician-Criminal Nexus 'Encountered'?
snippet.description:
Gangster Vikas Dubey was killed in an encounter after a road accident on Friday morning, while being taken to Kanpur in Uttar Pradesh. A lot of questions have also been raised over the UP Police's version. His death has now sparked off a political debate. Leaders from several political parties have raised questions at the encounter, wondering if it was orchestrated to prevent Dubey from revealing too much. From Mayawati and Akhilesh Yadav to Priyanka Gandhi and Manoj Jha, cutting across party lines, the demand is for a serious probe.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Local Issues Dead In Elections?
snippet.description:
The Haryana and Maharashtra state election campaigning could have been around a whole host of local issues. Economy, farmer distress, unemployment, drought, poverty, reservation for specific castes but what we have heard all through election campaigning is a discourse around the abrogation of Article 370 in Kashmir, implementation of Assam's NRC all over the country and only very recently ,the promise of giving Bharat Ratna to Vinayak Damodar Savarkar. The BJP has been winning elections on its own terms - challenging conventional campaigning wisdom. We find that even in many municipal elections, emotive issues like 370 has been spoken about, and in some cases, even worked. So on The Big Fight tonight, we ask just one simple question. Are local issues dead in elections? The problems may exist in real life, but do they simply not matter when voters go out and vote?

snippet.title: What is the best mode of investment?
snippet.description:
Real estate prices are down; stocks have seen some correction and the price of gold hasn't sky rocketed. The festival and wedding season is upon us, so is this the right time for investment and if so then what is the best mode of investment? Equity, residential property, gold, debt bonds or SIP-systematic investment planning? Generally the safest bet has been government schemes such as Fixed Deposits, PPF etc., but the rate of inflation has been higher than the returns in the last few years. So is it time to look beyond secured small savings schemes? What would common people do when it comes to equity? Should they leave it on fund managers or should a rookie person stay clear off the stock market as there are too much speculations. Will gold provide a cushion during hard times or should one invest in real estate right now to make a killing a few years down the line? If you are planning your investment but still considering where to put your money this is one Big Fight you must watch.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Holy cow, unholy vigilantes?
snippet.description:
There has been a spate of attacks on Dalits and minorities all across India in the last several weeks. These attacks that have been perpetuated by self-styled 'gau rakshaks' or cow protection groups were inspired largely by false rumours about their victims either transporting beef or skinning cows. Cow, being a sacred animal in India, has always been revered, however does this sanctify the use of violence against people who are either associated with the commerce around beef or by those who consume it? Cow Slaughter is prohibited in several states in India, but is that a crime punishable by public flogging or even death? Would it be right to assume that these attacks are carried out by a fanatical fringe independent of political patronage? Finally, does this hint towards the reality that caste discrimination is still prevalent in modern India? There are no easy answers here and that perhaps makes the debate even more relevant. All this and more on this latest episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Defence preparedness: Time for self-reliance?
snippet.description:
This week on The Big Fight, Defence Minister Manohar Parrikar and top defence manufacturers talks about a roadmap for defence production and 'Make in India'. While manufacturers said that the decision-making process needed to be speeded up, Mr Parrikar said that there was a direction now, but also issues that need to be sorted. Will increased Foreign Direct Investment limit help in making way for more foreign players in defence sector? Is bureaucratic lacunae leading to delay in acquisitions? Can India be a global arms exporter in the future? Why is India lacking in stealth component when it comes to Defence products?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Economy In ICU: Will Government's Growth Boosters Work?
snippet.description:
With the latest GDP numbers out at 4.5 per cent, the lowest since March 2013, it is clea that India's economy is in deep trouble. Car sales have gone down, factory output has shrunk, and exports have also slumped and the government's own data shows that rural spending has gone down, data the centre conveniently distanced itself from a couple of weeks ago. The government has tried to take steps to fix that in recent months and has slashed corporate taxes, set up a special real-estate fund, merged banks and announced the biggest privatization drive in more than a decade. While authorities are committed to doing more, the policy room may be narrowing. On The Big Fight , we ask with the economy in ICU, will government's growth boosters work?

snippet.title: Is Referendum 2019 A Referendum On PM Modi?
snippet.description:
The bitter, personal campaign for 2019 elections is over, and the question that arises now is finally, when all the votes are cast, what would have the people of India based their decision on. Is it the economy? Jobs? National security? Or just Narendra Modi. PM Modi's personality has loomed large over this election which many believe has simply been a referendum on him. Tonight, on 'The Big Fight', we ask: Is referendum 2019 a referendum on PM Modi, like the famous Time magazine cover says is he India's divider in chief or a great unifier?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is prohibition 'prohibitive'?
snippet.description:
Prohibition of alcohol is back on the political agenda with the AIADMK government in Tamil Nadu going ahead with phase-wise prohibition by shutting 500 shops. In April, Bihar had implemented complete prohibition - an electoral promise which the winning JD(U)-RJD coalition said was vital in getting support of female voters. In India, there has been an intermittent ban on production, sale and consumption of liquor in some states but they have rarely been successful. It only drove the business underground with bootleggers making hay backed by the mafia. The pro-prohibition lobby have often argued that too much of alcohol consumption leads to an increase led in domestic violence, impoverishment, particularly for those living on the fringes. But is there any factual relation between an increase in domestic violence and alcoholism? Will the ban result in a thriving bootlegging industry? Is the government overstepping on individual platform?

snippet.title: ISIS: Does it pose a real threat to India?
snippet.description:
On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we look at a group that shook the world with its acts of terror - the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria also known 'ISIS'. The extremely tech savvy terror group has made its plans for world domination very clear through various media channels, but how serious are these threats? Some might argue that it's a case of all show, no go. However, there are those who state that the sightings of ISIS flags in Kashmir have a different story to tell. The force which has been crowding our news feeds with videos of its gruesome executions, will be discussed by some of the finest thinkers in the field. We will also be joined by a family member of Areeb Majid, a young student who had travelled to Iraq to join the ISIS, but has since returned to India. We ask, does 'ISIS' pose a real threat to India? Does it deliberately target the young and the impressionable? What can India do to protect itself from this new threat?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/isis-does-it-pose-a-real-threat-to-india/380013?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Is There More Outrage Against Those Raising Voice Against Mob Killings?
snippet.description:
Earlier this week, the state of Rajasthan introduced a bill that proposes a tough new law to deal with incidents of mob killings. As per the bill, if the victim dies due to mob violence, people guilty of the crime will be given life sentences. Also, conspiracy to lynch will be treated as a crime equal to lynching itself. Is there less outrage over the lynchings and more at those who protest them? We discuss on The Big Fight.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are Gandhiji's ideals still relevant?
snippet.description:
Albert Einstein, perhaps the greatest of human minds, had once said on Mahatma Gandhi, “Generations to come will scarce believe that such a one as this ever in flesh and blood walked upon this Earth.” Today when more than six decades have passed since the Mahatma was laid to rest, has India moved away from his ideals? Are his ideas utopian or is it just that in a strife-torn World that we live in we need the Mahatma once more to restore our faith in humanity? What about his ideas on materialism, industrialisation, economic model? Did we junk them and pursue a contrarian course that would have shaken the Mahatma? But what if we imbibe and put to practice the Mahatma's way of life? Would the World be then a better place? Join us on an exciting debate on NDTV 24x7 on the relevance of Mahatma's ideas in today's World.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Citizenship Test -Is It Constitutional?
snippet.description:
Next week, the BJP government will bring to parliament the controversial Citizenship Amendment Bill which will for the first time in India seek to grant people citizenship based on their religion. The bill clearly says that non-Muslim minorities who face religious persecution in Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan are eligible for Indian citizenship. After huge protests in the northeast, the BJP made changes this week. So that it does not apply to autonomous tribal-dominated regions in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram and also to states that have the inner-line permit regime (Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland and Mizoram). However, that may not be enough in Assam, many groups feel that the CAB will nullify the 1985 Assam Accord, which fixed March 24, 1971 as the cut-off date for deportation of all illegal immigrants irrespective of religion. These groups feel that the CAB will selectively benefit non-Muslim migrants into Assam combined with the NRC or the National Register for Citizens, which aims to throw out illegal immigrants. The Citizenship bill could seriously deepen India's religious faultlines.

snippet.title: Maharashtra, Haryana Results: Has The Nationalism Card Run Its Course?
snippet.description:
The results are in for Maharashtra and Haryana but the story isn't over yet. In Maharashtra, the BJP's reduced numbers have made them more dependent on the Shiv Sena and the Sena is clearly playing hardball. In Haryana, the BJP will form the government with the help of Dushyant Chautala's JJP. The bigger question we ask on The Big Fight is: What do these polls tell us about what voters want, and which issues matter? The BJP campaigned aggressively on nationalist issues like Article 370 but that hasn't worked. With an economic crisis and other day-to-day issues affecting people more, does the nationalism card have its limits?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: 2019 Polls - NDA In Pole Position?
snippet.description:
Nitish Kumar's 'Ghar Wapsi' has thrown the opposition into complete disarray. The dream of weaving a grand coalition is now in tatters - with the loss of a clean, competent, credible face - now back in National Democratic Alliance's fold, the BJP's job for 2019 polls appears more than half done.  But is it so? Can the BJP increase its tally beyond 282 seats that they got in 2014 general elections? In the last general election, BJP swept Gujarat, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Chhattisgarh, Delhi, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand and reduced the opposition to a few seats in Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh. It's really difficult to increase its seats from these states. If NDA has to increase its tally it must look at those states where its performance was way below even satisfactory level - West Bengal, Odisha, Tamil Nadu, Kerala - where BJP won a paltry five seats out of 120. However, political experts believe that it is not the electoral arithmetic that works in India but rather the mood of the people, the 'wave' or the lack of it, that decides the outcome. No doubt, as of today, NDA under PM Narendra Modi is in an advantageous position and the opposition is grappling to figure out ways to counter him. But with elections more than a year-and-half away and the Indian electorate never failing to throw up a surprise, can a fight be completely written off?

But is it so? Can the BJP increase its tally beyond 282 seats that they got in 2014 general elections? In the last general election, BJP swept Gujarat, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Chhattisgarh, Delhi, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand and reduced the opposition to a few seats in Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh. snippet.title: The Big Fight | Crackdown On Dissent: Democracy In Descent?
snippet.description:
For more than a month now we have seen protests across India against the CAA and the NRC. Some of these protests began violently but most settled down into peaceful demonstrations, some have been hijacked by the political opposition, but what has been remarkable about many of them has been the lack of a leader, and the participation of women, of students, of ordinary people reading out the preamble to the Constitution reminding those who have forgotten what India really stands for. The Prime Minister talks about India's democracy - he said the Indian way of conflict avoidance is not by brute force but the power of dialogue, but where is his dialogue with the students who don't agree with his government?

snippet.title: Is it time to scrap Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code?
snippet.description:
An archaic British law, dating back over a hundred and fifty years is before the top court in India. The Supreme Court now needs to decide whether it is indeed time to scrap Section 377 of Indian Penal Code that criminalises homosexuality and makes gay sex illegal thereby infringing on the fundamental rights of the individual. Though attitudes towards homosexuality have undergone significant changes, it would only be fair to acknowledge that it is nonetheless a deeply divisive issue in India. Is this a matter of a majoritarian morality infringing upon the rights of the minority? Will the top court uphold its own legacy as a counter-majoritarian institution? Is the question of morality irrelevant when it comes to protecting the fundamental rights of an individual? We debate all this and more on The Big Fight.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | India's Farm Sector Reforms: Why Should Consensus Be The Casualty?
snippet.description:
The farmers' agitation has been going on for months now. But the last one week has seen a sudden flare up along Delhi's borders. Ultimately, the government listened. Meetings have taken place. Why a situation like this had to arise in the first place? Some experts notice a trend in the Central government's style of functioning - taking a decision at any cost instantly and then managing the consequences. Article 370, CAA, and now the farm laws -- all efforts on building the consensus come after a decision has been taken. On The Big Fight, we ask a very elementary question: Why is consensus the casualty?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Will Government Roll Back Farm Laws?
snippet.description:
After two days of face-offs, the authorities allowed protesting farmers, some of whom threw stones and broke barricade, to enter Delhi under police escort to stage a demonstration against agricultural reforms they fear will leave them at the mercy of big corporations. The police had deployed hundreds of personnel at different entry points to the national capital, parking trucks full of sand and laying barbed wire to block the farmers' path. The farmers have been upset with the laws passed earlier this year which mean they are now free to sell their produce to anyone at any price, instead of to state-controlled markets at assured rates. They say the new laws deregulating the vast agriculture sector will leave small growers vulnerable to corporate agri-businesses and could lead to a withdrawal of price supports for staples like wheat and rice. On The Big Fight, we ask: will the government roll back the farm laws?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: The Credibility Crisis In India's Institutions
snippet.description:
On this episode of The Big Fight, we look at the overall question of institutional integrity. The concept of other institutions becoming agents of the government was never a good idea. Institutional independence and integrity is one of the cornerstones of any democracy. If the rule of the law were to really operate, then we have to follow some checks and balances. Today, we look at all that's happening right now and discuss the ways to stop this.

snippet.title: Women's entry banned in places of worship: Discrimination or discretion?
snippet.description:
While gender rights activists have been up in arms against the discriminatory treatment meted out to women in Sabarimala, Haji Ali Dargah and Shani Shingnapur temple, the clergy and self-proclaimed custodians have cited custom and overwhelming 'consensus' among the faithful to support the continuation of the tradition. In 21st century India, has the time come to break these barriers or are there any spiritual, religious reasons behind these customs? Do women have equal rights vis-a-vis men in terms of right to worship? Do religions discriminate among men and women or is it the patriarchal clergy who are misinterpreting texts to hold their sway over the faithful? Is this a battle between the gender rights activists and patriarchal clergymen or a simple question of traditional rituals being dragged into controversy for no apparent reason?  Do write to us on what you think at bigfight@ndtv.com.

snippet.title: Pak probe team visits India: PM Modi's big gamble?
snippet.description:
Has the Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi taken a big risk in reposing faith on the Pakistani investigation team which is probing the Pathankot terror attack. What has changed in the course of three years that made PM Modi alter his stance of coming down heavily on Pakistan? Has Modi misplaced his political capital by investing his faith on Indo-Pak friendship? With China vetoing proscription of Jaish-e-Mohammed terrorist Masood Azhar will the double standard on the fight against terror be undermined? Will Pakistan continue to play the old game of hunting with the hound and running with the hare? What about the alleged Indian 'spy' Kulbhushan Yadav caught by the Pakistanis? Is he merely a prop, a cheap ploy by the military-Jihadi complex in Pakistan or is there something more there?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is Assam NRC A Humanitarian Disaster?
snippet.description:
It has been a colossal exercise in attempting to weed out illegal immigrants from Assam, an exercise that was always riddled in controversy and chaos. The National Register of Citizens or the NRC, aimed at identifying illegals, was published last Saturday after five years of being monitored by the Supreme Court. With its publication, it became even clearer that the whole exercise had been a colossal mess. Nearly two million people have been excluded in the final list, facing the possibility of being rendered stateless. And politically, it's a huge irony: the BJP which has championed the NRC and even called for it to be replicated across India, is today shocked that the final list has a large number of Bengali Hindus in it, they're convinced that the numbers from the high population Muslim areas are not accurate.

snippet.title: 'Tough Decision' on J&K: Change In Nuclear No-First Use Doctrine Next?
snippet.description:
Union Defence Minister Rajnath Singh today underscored that India reserves the right to change its policy of 'No First Use', which has been the cornerstone of India's nuclear weapons policy for decades. The government firmly stands by its 'No First Use' policy but "what happens in future will depend on the circumstances," the minister said at Pokhran in Rajasthan. The statement comes a day after the PM announced the creation of the post of Chief of Defence Staff. On The Big Fight, we discuss the consequences of making such statements in the current environment.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | PM Modi-Xi Jinping Meet: Can India Trust China?
snippet.description:
From Wuhan to Mamallapuram, it has been quite a journey for India and China over the last year. When Prime Minister Modi and President Xi Jinping met for their first informal summit in Wuhan in 2018, both countries struck the right tone, setting the stage for a good meeting. This year it has been quite different, with sharp words exchanged over Kashmir and Beijing hosting Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan on the eve of Xi's visit to India. The question we ask on The Big Fight is - can India and China find a middle ground in which to manage the relationship or does New Delhi need to be more realistic about dealing with China?

snippet.title: India of 2016: What would you like to change?
snippet.description:
As we enter a new year, we ask 'what are the things we'd like to change about India in 2016?'. We debated with a whole range of experts from various fields on what India needs to set right in 2016. The Parliament has to function and we need reforms to invigorate the economy. What about the instances of 'intolerance' that we witnessed through 2015; is it time for Indians to put a 'ban' on intolerance? Which way should our foreign policy focus? And finally what can we do to clean the urban mess that is our cities? For all this and more watch this new episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Climate change: How worried should you be?
snippet.description:
The World is standing at a crossroad where if we do not put a lid on the emission of greenhouse gases, in a few decades, we shall be heading towards an environmental disaster. With the climate change conference in Paris underway, will it be possible for various world leaders to look beyond blame game and actually hammer out an agreement that everyone will follow in letter and spirit? Should industrialised countries do more in terms of providing finance and accessibility to clean and green technology? In the long term how do we reduce our carbon footprint? Should developing countries adopt a minimum-carbon-consumption approach? If the world fails to arrive at an agreement on climate change in Paris then it might spell catastrophe for the world.  Join us for this week's episode of The Big Fight with Prakash Javadekar, Union Environment Minister, Sunita Narain, environmental activist and a whole set of experts from the climate change summit in Paris.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Are We Heading For One-Party Rule?
snippet.description:
What a week this has been. The Congress-JDS government in Karnataka is hanging by a thread. The congress has also seen a spectacular collapse in Goa, losing 10 of its 15 MLAs to the BJP, and in Delhi, the party has no clue who its leader is after Rahul Gnadhi's resignation. Seven weeks after the election results, the country's grand old party is facing an existential crisis. Then there are the regional parties who enjoyed a dominant role in the coalition era before 2014 and seemed to be giving the BJP the only real fight state-by-state. But look at their situation today. After winning just five seats in UP, Akhilesh Yadav, the head of the party, disappeared and went abroad, only to return to India earlier this week. Lalu Yadav's RJD, under his son Tejwaswi, got zero seats in Bihar - a first for the party which has been a powerful regional force. Tejwasi has been AWOL most of the last few weeks as well. Maywati didn't do that much better in UP, with 10 seats. Chandrababu Naidu's TDP is also unravelling quickly - four of his six Rajya Sabha MPs joined the BJP. The only parties that withstood the Modi wave were the DMK, the BJD, the TRS, and to some extent Mamata Banerjee's Trinamool Congress, but here too, the TMC is facing a strong challenge ahead of the Bengal state polls. Even the BJD isn't comfortable - they did well in the assembly poll but the BJP did well in the Lok Sabha election. With this massive mandate for PM Modi, and what seems to be an opposition that is withering away, are we heading towards one-party rule?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Is India More Casteist Than Ever Before?
snippet.description:
This week, the video of a young woman went viral on social media, in which she was pleading with her powerful politician father to back off and stop threatening her for marrying a man from a scheduled caste. The story of Sakshi Misra and her husband Ajitesh is right out of a bad Bollywood film - her father is a BJP lawmaker from UP, her husband Ajitesh was beaten up in the Allahabad High Court the other day - but it's a story that also represents the very cruel reality of caste in India. Our leaders often make big proclamations that India's caste divide is narrowing, that caste is slowly beginning to matter less in the way people vote, but is that true? When Mr Modi won his massive mandate in May, he said in his victory speech that "Only two castes will remain in this country: the poor and those who contribute whatever little to free the country from poverty." But is that narrative reflective of the reality on the ground? On the other hand, politically, the emergence of leaders like Chandrasheker Azad, who have challenged the BJP's brand of politics has also created a stir, but has it really made an impact? In this new India, is caste discrimination more entrenched than ever before?

snippet.title: 3 Years Of NaMo: Hits And Misses
snippet.description:
Change was the catchphrase in the run up to 2014 polls. Narendra Modi had promised us that he will transform India, end corruption, bring in industry, generate jobs, end social strife and forge a new path with neighbours and word powers. With his emphatic victory in the polls people were buoyed with the hope of a transformation that would herald a new era and catapult India towards a path of development. 

Three years have passed since Narendra Modi was anointed as the Prime Minister of the country. While the government has certainly succeeded in bringing down inflation, tackling corruption its failure to generate enough jobs has invited criticism from all quarters. While electorally, BJP had its best performance in Jammu and Kashmir, the sharp slide in the internal security condition of the state has put several question marks over its inability to come up with a new strategy to deal with the impending crisis.

While time and again, PM Modi has reiterated his mantra of 'Sabka Saath Sabka Vikaas', the highhandedness of Gau Rakshaks and other fringe groups have undermined the government's desire to take along all sections of the society. 

The realm of foreign policy has been really tricky for this government. With a changing geo-political scenario the government has been grappling with new ways and strategies - especially when it comes to Pakistan and China. While India's relation with Bangladesh and Nepal has improved a series of flip flops with Pakistan and China's belligerence stance and disregard for India's security concerns have hemmed in the Modi government into a corner. China has blocked India's entry to NSG and vetoed UN sanctions against terrorist Masood Azhar. It seems that it will be a long winding road for India.

snippet.title: Delhi Violence: From Courts To Police, No Hope For Victims?
snippet.description:
As the number of dead and injured climbs up steadily in the aftermath of over four days of violence in Northeast Delhi last week, questions are being raised on the efficacy of India's public institutions. Controversy surrounds the role of the Delhi police and the midnight transfer of a Delhi High Court judge soon after passing a tough order. On the Big Fight, we discuss, is Delhi the symptom of a larger malaise? Have India's institutions failed its citizens?  And in such a scenario, what can clash victims hope for?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Will Backing Sajad Lone Hurt BJP in Jammu?
snippet.description:
With the Jammu and Kashmir governor having dissolved the state assembly in what many are calling a hasty manner, and with arch rivals National Conference and the PDP showing that no alliance is off the table in politics - all eyes are now on the centre. snippet.title: Uri Attack Fallout: What Are India's Options?
snippet.description:
The death of 18 soldiers in Uri attack this month, is perhaps the most belligerent attack staged  by Pakistan-based terrorists during Prime Minister Narendra Modi's regime. PM Modi, who had caustically remarked on the soft posturing of the UPA government during terror attacks, now finds himself in a unenviable position where under immense pressure from public and political parties, he has to match up his rhetoric or come up with a solution that serves him to contain the surge of domestic anger against India's neighbour. Pathankot attack sounded the death knell of the peace process that Prime Minister Narendra Modi had begun early in his tenure. Now after the barbaric attack in Uri, is a military strike the only option? Or should India consider covert, targeted attacks in Pakistan? Does India have the covert capabilities to hurt Pakistan? Has the diplomatic push by the Modi government yielded any result? Will the world, especially the US, put pressure on Pakistan to take action against radical anti-India elements? Or despite being labelled as a 'soft' state time and again, India will have to fall back upon the very well-traversed road of condemning Pakistan's terror activities by opening a new channel of dialogue?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/uri-attack-fallout-what-are-india-s-options-432530?yt

snippet.title: 6 Dead In Violence Across Uttar Pradesh During Citizenship Act Protests
snippet.description:
Six protesters were killed in clashes that erupted across Uttar Pradesh over the Citizenship Amendment Act on Friday, the state police confirmed. This has taken the total number of protest-related deaths in the state to seven so far. However, Uttar Pradesh Director General of Police OP Singh claimed that none of the protesters were killed in police firing. "We did not shoot even a single bullet," he said, even as another officer claimed that "if any firing happened, it was from the protesters' side".

snippet.title: Big Fight Diwali Special: What Is The Best Mode Of Investment?
snippet.description:
With interest rates on safe and secure small savings schemes lowering year after year, when it is not even possible to match inflationary figures anymore, where does one invest? Real Estate? Does the quest for a 'home' stand a chance as the only sector where prices stand corrected? Or should one invest 'systematically' in mutual funds which for the past few years has consistently given returns higher than the average inflationary figure? What about investing in the stock market? Can those who have limited knowledge about stocks bear the ups and downs the market offers? Or should people repose their faith on the time tested, age-old mode of investment and exchange, gold? Join us on The Big Fight as we bring to you professional experts, financial planners, fund managers to help you decide on the best mode of investment this Diwali

snippet.title: Big Fight Over Finance Bill Amendments
snippet.description:
The government brought in 40 amendments to the Finance Bill 2017, some of which are contentious with opposition, constitutional experts branding them as not a 'open and shut' case to be part of a 'Money Bill'. Now Money Bills, according to the constitution, need not be passed or amended by the Rajya Sabha, where the BJP is in minority. So were the reforms in contravention to the basic spirit of the Constitution? Did the BJP brought in 'allied reforms' in the Finance Bill and not as a separate Bill to evade the Rajya Sabha? Are the poll reforms, vesting more powers on Income Tax officers, making Aadhaar mandatory for filing I-T returns and making sweeping changes to Appellate Tribunals a subversion of constitution? The government, in its defence, is falling back to previous UPA and NDA regimes where poll reforms were tagged along the Finance Bill. The other controversial justification, which the spin doctors of the government are providing is that the Upper House of the Parliament cannot block 'people's wishes' as was evident through BJP's victories in a number of elections post 2014.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: The Political Roadmap To 2019
snippet.description:
It has been a week of two major developments that may have an impact on national politics. First, the elections in Gujarat and Himachal Pradesh and second, the landmark judgement on the 2G spectrum scam. The 2G scam was one of the major factors that cost UPA the last Lok Sabha elections and now the court has acquitted all those charged with the scam. Will these developments have a far reaching impact on the politics of the country? For all this and more, watch this week's episode of The Big Fight.
